publicwhip.spmotion: *S1M-1831# Mr John McAllion: Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland—That the Parliament, while welcoming the presence in Scotland of the independent charity "Public Concerns at Work", urges the Scottish Executive to take reasonable and proper account of the implications of public interest whistle-blowing for all areas of its work and to promote and deliver openness, accountability and good governance throughout Scotland and further calls upon the Scottish Executive to undertake an education campaign to inform the people of Scotland of the implications, protections and benefits of public interest whistle-blowing as it affects the conduct of public, private and voluntary organisations throughout Scotland.
S1M-1831# Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland (lodged on 5 April 2001) Irene Oldfather*

S1M-1831# Mr John McAllion: Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland—That the Parliament, while welcoming the presence in Scotland of the independent charity "Public Concerns at Work", urges the Scottish Executive to take reasonable and proper account of the implications of public interest whistle-blowing for all areas of its work and to promote and deliver openness, accountability and good governance throughout Scotland and further calls upon the Scottish Executive to undertake an education campaign to inform the people of Scotland of the implications, protections and benefits of public interest whistle-blowing as it affects the conduct of public, private and voluntary organisations throughout Scotland. Supported by: Irene Oldfather, Tommy Sheridan*
S1M-1831# Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland (lodged on 5 April 2001) Mr Michael McMahon*, Donald Gorrie*, Tricia Marwick*
S1M-1831# Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland (lodged on 5 April 2001) Mr Kenneth Gibson*, Rhoda Grant*, Robin Harper*, Scott Barrie*

S1M-1831# Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland (lodged on 5 April 2001) Mr Adam Ingram*, Elaine Smith*, Mary Scanlon*, Ms Sandra White*, Cathy Peattie*

S1M-1831# Mr John McAllion: Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland—That the Parliament, while welcoming the presence in Scotland of the independent charity "Public Concerns at Work", urges the Scottish Executive to take reasonable and proper account of the implications of public interest whistle-blowing for all areas of its work and to promote and deliver openness, accountability and good governance throughout Scotland and further calls upon the Scottish Executive to undertake an education campaign to inform the people of Scotland of the implications, protections and benefits of public interest whistle-blowing as it affects the conduct of public, private and voluntary organisations throughout Scotland. Supported by: Irene Oldfather, Tommy Sheridan, Mr Michael McMahon, Donald Gorrie, Tricia Marwick, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Rhoda Grant, Robin Harper, Scott Barrie, Margaret Jamieson, David Mundell, Mr Duncan Hamilton, Michael Russell, Nora Radcliffe, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Mr Adam Ingram, Elaine Smith, Mary Scanlon, Ms Sandra White, Cathy Peattie
S1M-1831# Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland (lodged on 5 April 2001) Pauline McNeill*, Nicola Sturgeon*, Bristow Muldoon*

Supported by: Irene Oldfather, Tommy Sheridan, Mr Michael McMahon, Donald Gorrie, Tricia Marwick, Mr Kenneth Gibson, Rhoda Grant, Robin Harper, Scott Barrie, Margaret Jamieson, David Mundell, Mr Duncan Hamilton, Michael Russell, Nora Radcliffe, Mrs Mary Mulligan, Mr Adam Ingram, Elaine Smith, Mary Scanlon, Ms Sandra White, Cathy Peattie, Pauline McNeill, Nicola Sturgeon, Bristow Muldoon, Mr Gil Paterson

S1M-1831# Mr John McAllion: Public Interest Whistle-blowing in Scotland—That the Parliament, while welcoming the presence in Scotland of the independent charity "Public Concerns at Work", urges the Scottish Executive to take reasonable and proper account of the implications of public interest whistle-blowing for all areas of its work and to promote and deliver openness, accountability and good governance throughout Scotland and further calls upon the Scottish Executive to undertake an education campaign to inform the people of Scotland of the implications, protections and benefits of public interest whistle-blowing as it affects the conduct of public, private and voluntary organisations throughout Scotland.
